ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned lots during my rotation about different methods and possible thesis projects.
Exposed to different research background and lab atomosphere
During my first two rotations, I learned many new techniques, including cell culture, RNA isolation and qPCR, and fluorescence microscopy.
I learned different tricks to expand the techniques I already know and learned new ones. I had the opportunity to sample to different research labs to find the best fit for me.
The rotations gave me a good opportunity to check out labs that I am interested in at Yale.
I learned the lab atmosphere and some new techniques. Also I was exposed to presenting my research in different settings.
It's hard to list all the skills and insights I acquired during my rotations, but they were certainly diverse and numerous.
The rotations were great, learned a lot of practical skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the rotations could be improved if it was more clear to all faculty that we are also taking classes and have a lot going on. The first semester was honestly extremely chaotic and not very enjoyable because we were working 12-15 hours a day basically 6 days a week with rotations and classes and many of us often felt pressured to be in the lab all the time even when we had lots of coursework to do. In addition, I think being able to give constructive feedback to faculty members about rotations, similar to how they give us feedback would be very helpful!
Lab rotations provide an excellent environment for getting to know the research and operations of a lab.
Flash talks should be given before rotations start. Maybe start rotations earlier so we dont have to deal with finals week and the end of our rotation?
The first rotation should begin sooner into the semester. The second one should end before reading week, it was hard to do lab work and study for my finals.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, being exposed to a lab prior to joining the lab is critical.
Of course, you get to test a lab before officially joining it while gaining fantastic, hands-on experience.
